<!-- PROJECT OVERVIEW SLIDE -->

<div>

<h2>Project Overview</h2>

</div>

::: {style="text-align: center;font-size: 45px;"}
<ul>

<li>Compare the impact of NO2 and SO2 on hospital admissions, identifying the pollutant with the strongest correlation.</li>

<li>Analyze how air pollution affects different age groups and specific health conditions, such as respiratory diseases.</li>

<li>Visualize geographic disparities in health impacts using a heatmap, highlighting areas most vulnerable to air pollution.</li>

</ul>
:::

<!-- WHY THE ANALYSIS MATTERS SLIDE -->

## Why It Matters:

::: {style="text-align: center;font-size: 45px;"}
<ul>

<li>Understanding the effects of NO2 and SO2 on hospital admissions helps shape more effective pollutant-specific health interventions.</li>

<li>Analyzing how these pollutants impact different age groups enables targeted public health strategies for vulnerable populations.</li>

<li>Assessing the impact of these pollutants on different areas across the city helps allocate medical resources more effectively.</li>

</ul>
:::

<!-- DATA DESCRIPTION SLIDE -->

## What is our data?

::: {style="text-align: center;font-size: 45px;"}
<ul>

<li>The data includes NO2 and SO2 concentration levels across Pittsburgh neighborhoods, grouped by city blocks.</li>

<li>It tracks hospital admissions for respiratory and cardiovascular illnesses, categorized by specific health conditions.</li>

<li>Demographic information helps identify vulnerable populations affected by air pollution across different city blocks.</li>

</ul>
:::

#### Discoveries

<u>

<h3>Insights Derived</h3>

</u>

::: {style="text-align: center;font-size: 45px;"}
<ul>

<li>A positive correlation was observed between higher NO₂ and SO₂ concentrations and increased hospital admissions for respiratory conditions.</li>

<li>Block groups near industrial zones exhibited the highest pollutant levels and hospital admissions, suggesting environmental and health inequities.</li>

</ul>
:::

<!-- CONCLUSION SLIDE -->

## Conclusion

::: {style="text-align: center;font-size: 45px;"}
<ul>

<li>The study connects NO₂ and SO₂ pollution to higher respiratory health risks, particularly in urban and industrial areas.</li>

<li>Vulnerable groups, such as children and the elderly, suffer more from pollution’s health effects.</li>

<li>The visual insights highlight the need for focused healthcare measures, improved zoning regulations, and cleaner industrial practices to reduce health disparities.</li>

</ul>
:::
